text.__SUMMARY__: The  Trinidad worm snake (Amerotyphlops trinitatus), also known commonly as the Trinidad burrowing snake, is a harmless blind snake species in the family Typhlopidae. The species is endemic to Trinidad and Tobago. There are no subspecies that are recognized as being valid.
text.Description: A. trinitatus grows to a maximum total length (including tail) of 24 cm (9.4 in).
text.Geographic range: Found mostly on the island of Tobago, A. trinitatus is known from widely scattered locations, and from a single location on the island of Trinidad, which happens to be the type locality. This is described as "Trinidad [County of St. George], ... Arima Road, 3 miles above [north of] Simla [Research Station]".
text.Further reading:
Hedges SB, Marion AB, Lipp KM, Marin J, Vidal N (2014). A taxonomic framework for typhlopid snakes from the Caribbean and other regions (Reptilia, Squamata). Caribbean Herpetology (49): 1-61. (Amerotyphlops trinitatus, new combination).
Richmond ND (1965). "A new species of blind snake, Typhlops, from Trinidad". Proc. Biol. Soc. Washington 78: 121-124. (Typhlops trinitatus, new species).
text.External links: Amerotyphlops trinitatus at the Reptarium.cz Reptile Database. Accessed 29 January 2016.
